Interesting. I was hoping that it would end quickly just like Legall's famous game, but my hopes were futile.
A bit of a poor move by Black. I already have two knights developed and Black should instead focus on a move like 3. ... Nf6 or 3. ... Nc6.
A bit of a poor move by Black. I already have two knights developed and Black should instead focus on a move like 3. ... Nf6 or 3. ... Nc6.
Sure, Black's pawn on h6 was helping to stop my knight coming to g5, but I sensed that I had an advantage here.
Sure, Black's pawn on h6 was helping to stop my knight coming to g5, but I sensed that I had an advantage here.
This is an alright move, as I wanted to open up the position. 5. d3 might have been better.
I decide to recapture using the queen instead of the knight. Black is very open to attack and so has to be careful.
I decide to recapture using the queen instead of the knight. Black is very open to attack and so has to be careful.
A mistake. I can now capture the pawn on g7.
Unfortunately, I didn't see it. Instead, I block the possibility. After 7. Qxg7, Black can only defend the rook with 7. ... Bf6, after which I can play Qxf7#.
Now Black is in serious trouble.
Now Black is in serious trouble.
Now Black is in serious trouble.
This is similar to Scholar's Mate, but with one vital difference. Black's king can run to d7.
Black gets greedy. Not something you want to do when you're in this type of situation.

Stunning. I never would have expected myself to pull something like this off. If you wish to leave me a suggestion for an annotated game, or want to leave me feedback, please drop me a message. Your help is appreciated.
